transcript:
Patient: Mindfulness sounds like it could be helpful for managing my anxiety in the moment. Can you give me an example of how I could use it during a social interaction?

Therapist: Absolutely, Priya. Let's imagine you're having a conversation with a friend, and you start to feel anxious and have negative thoughts like "They don't really want to be here" or "I'm just bothering them." In that moment, you can take a brief pause and focus on your breath. Notice the sensation of the air moving in and out of your lungs, the rise and fall of your chest. If your mind starts to wander back to the anxious thoughts, gently redirect your attention to your breath.

By focusing on your breath, you're anchoring yourself in the present moment and giving yourself a break from the negative thoughts. This can help reduce the intensity of the anxiety and make it easier to refocus on the conversation. With practice, mindfulness can become a valuable tool for managing anxiety in social situations.

Patient: That makes sense. I'll try to remember to focus on my breath the next time I start feeling anxious in a conversation. It's just hard to break out of that cycle of negative thoughts sometimes.

Therapist: You're right, it can be challenging to break out of that cycle. That's why practicing mindfulness regularly, even when you're not feeling particularly anxious, can be helpful. The more you practice, the easier it becomes to use mindfulness in moments of anxiety.

Another technique that can be helpful in managing negative thoughts is reframing. This involves taking a negative thought and finding a more balanced, realistic perspective. For example, instead of thinking "I'm just bothering them," you could reframe it as "They chose to spend time with me, so they must value our friendship on some level."

Reframing can help you see situations in a more balanced light and reduce the power of negative thoughts. It's a skill that takes practice, but over time, it can become a valuable tool for managing anxiety and negative thoughts.

Patient: I like the idea of reframing. It's just hard to come up with those alternative perspectives in the moment when I'm feeling really anxious.

Therapist: That's a great point, Priya. One way to make reframing easier is to practice it outside of anxiety-provoking situations. You can start by writing down some common negative thoughts you have and then brainstorming alternative perspectives for each one. Over time, this practice can help you build the skill of reframing, making it easier to do in the moment when you're feeling anxious.

Another helpful technique is to have some go-to reframes that you can use in moments of anxiety. For example, you could remind yourself "Everyone feels awkward sometimes" or "One awkward moment doesn't define the whole interaction." Having these go-to reframes can give you something to cling to when your mind is flooded with negative thoughts.

Patient: Those are good ideas. I'll try to come up with some go-to reframes for myself and practice reframing outside of anxious moments. I guess it's just going to take a lot of practice to get better at managing my anxiety and negative thoughts.

Therapist: You're absolutely right, Priya. Managing anxiety and negative thoughts is a skill that takes practice. It's not always easy, but with consistent effort, it does get easier over time. Remember to be patient and compassionate with yourself as you work on these skills. Progress isn't always linear, and that's okay.

I also want to acknowledge the effort you've been putting into our sessions and the work you're doing outside of therapy. Challenging negative thoughts and beliefs is hard work, and you're doing a great job of engaging with the process. Keep practicing these techniques, and over time, I believe you'll start to notice a shift in your thoughts and feelings.
